959020349982638080.text: Check out the whitepaper draft, slides and the new video at http://userfeeds.io  if you're interested in learning more.

959020348086915072.text: The solution we propose with the @userfeeds protocol and its implementations is to make this personalization process transparent. The user should always know how their personalized reality is constructed and where on the consensual-personal spectrum they’re currently at.

959020346405019649.text: The problem is that their ‘news’, while consensual, is not personalized - just series of 0s and 1s. They need personalization to be meaningful to humans - via user interfaces, narratives, stories etc. Through personalization - meaning is gained, but the consensus is lost.

959020344744054786.text: The solution lies in consensus algorithms that allow us to come to an agreement and build shared realities. Cryptocurrency miners are the news companies of the blockchain age. They report who did what, in what order, and what’s the resulting state of affairs.

959020343099822080.text: We see the “fake news” problem as a syndrome of personalization algorithms pushing us too far into our individual realities. Extraction of attention through personalization is a lucrative business model of Silicon Valley but it shovels people into a virtual reality of one.

959020341376049153.text: ’Money’ is the ultimate consensual reality, ‘your dream last night’ is the ultimate personal reality. Applying the ‘real-fake’ model to them is meaningless as they’re both illusions. But human illusions impact our behaviours as if they were true.

959020339618512897.text: At @userfeeds we believe the basic dichotomy of the information society won’t be ‘real-fake’ but ‘consensual-personal’. Consensus will help us establish shared frames of reference with others. Personalization will add flavour and meaning based on our individual context.

959020338150559744.text: I’m fascinated by the “fake news” problem as it forces our society to revisit the basic assumptions about what’s ‘real’ in the information age. The common narrative is that the solution to “fake news” is more fact-checking. As if there’s a “real” reality that we can fact-check.

953933402343903232.text: The @userfeeds protocol and our current implementation in the form of the userfeeds relevance platform, will enables the relevance algorithms that will integrate these two dimensions of relevance in space and time.

953933399105916928.text: To make it more precise, it’s not that “time” doesn’t exist on Facebook. It’s just that the expectations about the future are not stored in “likes”. They’re stored in your crypto buys.

953933396387991552.text: If you want to internalize this idea, watch yourself scrolling through the feed (in space, up& down, no time) and watching the crypto charts (in time, back and forth). Also watch yourself how you think when you click ‘like’ and when you click ‘buy’.

953933392487354368.text: What’s even more important is that these “time-based” preferences will end up on the open data layers and will allow to us to rank ideas not only in space as we do today (with links and likes) but also in time.

953933387546361856.text: Tokenization is so important because it allows masses of people reveal their preferences about the future relevance of even the smallest ideas. Trading and speculation has a very important to role to play in the information society.

953933384585285632.text: So today, only public companies can be “ranked” based on expectations about their future, context-independent relevance (buy/sells) but other types of information can be only ranked based on their present, contextual relevance (links/likes).

953933381464657921.text: The component of “time” exists in financial networks where traders are nodes and buy/sell transactions are edges. An agent buying an asset reveals a different kind of information to the network - “what they expect to be relevant to other agents in the future”.

953933378633523200.text: There’s lots of relevance to be extracted from these signals as stories of GOOG and FB can prove. However, these signals only exist in “space” but don’t contain the component of “time”.

953933375894704128.text: The idea is that preferences agents reveal in links, likes & clikcs only reveal information in one dimension. They provide the network with an answer to the question - “what is relevant to an agent  in their context in the present moment”.

953933372744663040.text: The possible remedies we explore and will present soon rely on mixing “consensual” relevance of money (enabled by blockchains and tokens) with “personalized”, contextual relevance we know from GOOG and FB.

953933369838133249.text: At @userfeeds we think it’s much more productive to recognize this fundamental law of the network - that agents seeking relevance in the system will always try to make other agents more “predictable” via various means.

953933366964948992.text: Once we understand that the problem we have as a  society with “fake news” and digital addiction has an information-theoretic underpinning we’ll realize that “fact-checking” and “turn off your phone” will never work at scale.

953933363877998592.text: In that sense, what we call “fake news” is not an anomaly but a natural evolution that optimizes the system for more relevance. No matter what we think of them, they’re relevant in the information theoretic sense. They’re predictive of people’s actions.

953933361235578880.text: The role of aggregators (like GOOG or FB) is simply to “compress” information stored in links and likes to extract as much relevance as possible. It’s all about predictability.

953933358186356736.text: “The relevant information in an action x of a person X is the information that this action provides about another action y of a person Y.” An Instagram post by a celebrity -> product sales, Facebook photo posted -> Facebook likes, tweet -> retweets.

953933355028017153.text: The paper provides a theoretical explanation of mechanisms behind deep learning and neural networks. Where it gets interesting is when you extrapolate this definition to the Web at large. We can define relevance on the Web and especially social networks as:

953933350833737728.text: The quantitative definition of ‘information relevance’ proposed by the authors was an eye-opener. Everything suddenly made sense. Here it goes:pic.twitter.com/1cEvKU9dXn

953933333473447936.text: Most people intuitively understand ‘relevance’ but are unable to provide a precise definition. This was also our problem when explaining ideas behind Userfeeds and the attention economy. We used examples but always felt we lack precision and generality.

953933318109761536.text: Thread - “Why Fake News Are Relevant”. One of the most insightful papers I’ve read in the recent months was - “The information bottleneck method” https://arxiv.org/pdf/physics/0004057.pdf … - with it’s quantitative definition of ‘information relevance’.

921836403075485698.text: 11/ Therefore, valuations of crypto-networks should be based on the *observations* they can attract in the finite attention pool.

921836401267826688.text: 10/ Crypto-networks natively operate in the ‘attention economy’ and compete for *observations* that are scarce.

921836399204163584.text: 9/ Token enables ranking & reputation signals such as price that most agents will use under imperfect information and limited attention.

921836397497061376.text: 8/ The token itself is the ‘customer acquisition mechanism’ for the underlying utility that otherwise would be undiffrentiated.

921836395815108608.text:
7/ What if utility tokens are all about influencing preferences and actions of other agents to ‘join’ 
a particular instance of the network.

921836394011594752.text: 6/ At the same time, their own preferences are NOT fixed either as they’re being influenced by actions of other agents.

921836392308793349.text: 5/ Attention of agents is scarce so they’ll have to rely on heuristics and signals from other agents to make decisions and take actions.

921836390568157185.text: 4/ But in the information economy that’s not true. Agents don’t have perfect knowledge and don’t know what they exactly want.

921836388894625793.text: 3/ The existing valuation models assume perfect knowledge of potential users about all alternative instances and their own preferences.

921836387166539778.text: 2/ Infinite number of alternatives can be created by running the instance of the open source code.

920354703304732672.text: 12/ Tokens, being digital, can be interpreted as pure signaling to drive usage of commoditized, open-sourced functionality. [end]

920354701593411586.text: 11/ The 90% of value of commoditized physical goods comes from their ‘signaling’ utility. Open source commoditizes the code.

920354699827666950.text: 10/ Just like a celebrity who wears our $199 t-shirt in public, provides value to other owners of that t-shirt.

920354697680125963.text: 9/ Therefore, investors who only buy and hoard (esp long term) without ‘utilizing’ are providing actual value to the network.

920354695914409990.text: 8/ What’s valuable is the particular instantiation of that code, the culture, the team & community behind it. That will impact the price.

920354693993390085.text: 7/ With open-source networks, anyone can copy the code and run their own token. The code itself is the commodity, the $1USD t-shirt.

920354692483506176.text: 6/ So the ‘intended utility’ evolves towards signaling utility as the underlying good/service gets commoditized.

920354690407247873.text: 5/ What you buy for $199 is the reputational signal that you belong to a group and that gets you scarce attention of others in that group.

920354688888901633.text: 4/ So why people will pay $200 for a t-shirt? Because ‘keeping you clothed’ is a commodity already. The $199 is the scarce signaling value.

920354687118962689.text: 3/ What is the ‘intended utility’ of a t-shirt? The obvious answer is to keep you clothed but that is satisfied by a $1 t-shirt.

920354685281816576.text: 2/ These are *intuitions* rather than convictions so please don’t shoot if you disagree. It’s food for thought rather than anything else.

915901128595951616.text: 4/ Generally, following what *feels* right stops being a good fitness strategy. Your feelings evolved for the previous environment.

915901124611362816.text: 2/ This new scarcity will be *counterintuitive* to everyone raised under previous conditions. Most will keep chasing the old scarcity.

915619895827681280.text: 11/ The „separation of powers” between agents controlling the state, algorithms and UX will provide „checks and balances” in the system.

915619893919256581.text: 10/ In the future, tokens will enable „circles of influence” where token holders will influence actions of each other via open states.

915619891629232133.text: 9/ Right now, the most observed states are controlled by privately owned entities with exclusive access.

915619889695657984.text: 8/ The more observations of a given state, the more influence on future actions its controllers have and more value flows to them.

915619887879524354.text: 7/ b) they are the mechanism of decentralised control and over that state. Your private key is a write access to the database.

915619886130491392.text: 6/ a) they drive observations of their state away from other states. People pay most attention to what they and others own.

915619883890696193.text: 5/ From that perspective, tokens are interesting because of two things:

915619881835536384.text: 4/ In the attention economy, value is control over a state, that’s frequently observed, because you control what people see and act on.

915619879692193792.text: 3/ The combination of newsfeeds, posts, notifications, VR are just a mechanism of systematically attracting a pool of attention.

915619877741883392.text: 2/ What Facebook sells is influence on future actions of their users categorized by interests,  demographics etc.

915619875405668353.text: 1/ If you think „decentralized Facebook” will be a blue website with a newsfeed but on the blockchain you’re missing the point.

914810605776797696.text: 5/ The blockchain projects start from openly and formally describing their incentives. They actually *are* the incentive structure.

914810604149460992.text: 4/ The „meta-incentive” of the existing centralized players of the Web 1.0 and Web 2.0 is to hide their real incentives from users.

914810602001969152.text: 3/ We carry apps modeled after slot machines in our pockets because of this hidden incentives. The newsfeed didn’t evolve in a vacuum.

914810599812534273.text: 2/ But with Facebook the incentives are hidden and opaque. They combine 17th century corporate structure with 21st attention economics.

914810597933543427.text: 1/ The current shape of Twitter/Facebook or any other global online platform is a result of incentive structures as much as Bitcoin is.

913727268702359554.text: 20/ Tokens and cryptographically signed messages allow us to build signaling mechanisms and algorithms where incentives are transparent.

913727266168954880.text: 19/ Without understanding the alignment of incentives between you and the message sender, you won’t be able to evaluate the message.

913727263539163137.text: 18/ Therefore relying on content of messages to determine their value will be misguided.

913727260665970688.text: 17/ Having the largest set of choices and being the most unpredictable will be the mark of freedom and true wealth in the attention economy.

913727257813901312.text: 16/ Whoever controls your state of attention and your menu of available actions, controls the most valuable scarcity of the 21st century.

913727255305756672.text: 15/ The idea of truth etc is irrelevant. If I feed your false beliefs, it’s cheaper for me to get and redirect your attention elsewhere.

913727252541722624.text: 14/ Generating digital addiction, confirming existing biases, fake news etc are all symptoms of attention economy working as intended.

913727249811156997.text:
13/ That’s why companies like Facebook have to:
1. accumulate more data about observer
2. make their users addicted to the service

913727247072325632.text: 12/ The more predictably you can elicit future (valuable) actions from observers, the more wealth will flow to you in the attention economy.

913727244589309952.text: 11/ If you can change the probability of what „be seen” you change the probability of what will be acted upon.

913727241846214656.text: 10/ „Content creators” become „influencers”. It’s not about the content you produce, it’s about your influence on future actions.

913727239275122693.text: 9/ In the past it was control over land, then control over capital & labor, now it’s control over frequently observed states of information.

913727236796231680.text: 8/ Wealth in the attention economy means control over future states of attention and future actions of the observers.

913727234388701184.text: 7/ The fundamental scarcity in the attention economy is the scarcity of observations and actions that observers can make in the future.

913727231037493248.text: 6/ An agent with write access to the state of information that’s frequently observed has influence over future actions of observers.

913727227967283200.text: 5/ Observer’s „free will” is limited to the menu of choices at hand. „What You See Is All There Is”.

913727225530372096.text: 4/ The state of attention of the observer determines and limits the set of choices the observer can make while in that state.

913727223009562624.text: 3/ Through the act of observation a state of information (e.g. a blog post) becomes a state of attention of the observer.

913727220400746496.text: 2/ There are *states of information* (external, objective, computational) and *states of attention* (internal, subjective, neurocognitive).
